title: US hedge fund bets £70m on controversial Cobham takeover by Advent
text:
A hedge fund based in New York has staked £70million on the controversial Cobham takeover getting the green light from the Government.

Business Secretary Andrea Leadsom asked the Competition and Markets Authority watchdog to research whether the £4billion deal for the defence firm by US private equity outfit Advent posed a risk to national security. The CMA is due to report its findings on Tuesday.

Concerns about the deal centre on Cobham’s specialist technologies – such as its air-to-air refuelling systems and electronic warfare gadgetry used by the RAF.

Westchester Capital has built a 1.8% stake in Cobham worth nearly £70m

Westchester Capital, a hedge fund which specialises in cashing in on takeovers, has quietly built up a 1.8 per cent stake in Cobham worth nearly £70million since the deal was announced.

The fund will make heavy losses if the merger is blocked. However, Westchester portfolio manager Roy Behren is optimistic that the deal will go through.

He told The Mail on Sunday: ‘We think this particular transaction has very limited anti-trust risk, but there are some sensitive technologies involved.

‘Cobham would need Government approval to sell this technology to any bad actors, so we are relatively confident the deal will happen.’
